body: I think mypy's behavior is correct here. See [this pyright issue](https://github.com/microsoft/pyright/issues/7712) for details.

I mean, `Foo.BAR` is an instance of `Foo`, so why shouldn't I be able to use `Self` to describe it, and avoid repetition?

In my real world use case I have an enum with many class methods that return `Self` or `list[Self]`, so it would be quite a repetition to mention `Foo` instead in all these places.

> why shouldn't I be able to use Self to describe it?

`Self` doesn't mean "any instance of the containing class", and it's not intended to be a shortcut to specify that class in an annotation. `Self` has a very specific meaning and intended use in the typing spec. It is a type variable whose type has an upper bound of the containing class. It is also the type of the `self` or `cls` parameter. For more details, refer to [this section of the typing spec](https://typing.readthedocs.io/en/latest/spec/generics.html#self).

An annotation of `Self` in your example indicates that the method will return an instance of whatever class was passed for the `cls` parameter. If your intent is for the method to return an instance of `Foo`, the method should be annotated as such.

In this specific case, it's not possible to subclass `Foo` (right?), so I think it would be valid for mypy to assume that `Self` always gets bound to `Foo`.  Mypy already makes a similar assumption when `Self` appears in the body of class that is annotated with `@final`.

> In this specific case, it's not possible to subclass `Foo` (right?), so I think it would be valid for mypy to assume that `Self` always gets bound to `Foo`. Mypy already makes a similar assumption when `Self` appears in the body of class that is annotated with `@final`.

I made the same argument in https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/16558#issuecomment-1826276358, but others argued that doing this would require a change to the typing spec. I still think it would be a useful improvement that would make life more ergonomic for users of enums without any detriment to type safety (but I haven't got the time/energy to push for a change to the spec on this point right now, if it does indeed require a chnage to the spec)

I found a workaround that will let me use `Self`: https://mypy-play.net/?mypy=master&python=3.12&gist=35585f6a10b359f79d7e660d547aaa5c

```python
from enum import *
from typing import *

T = TypeVar("T")

class _FooImpl:
    @classmethod
    def get_bar(cls) -> Self:
        return cls.BAR  # type: ignore

class Foo(_FooImpl, Enum):
    BAR = "bar"


reveal_type(Foo.get_bar())
```

although it would be nicer if we could just define the `get_bar` function in the actual `Foo` enum class, as this workaround really destroys the reading flow.
plus, it requires to use a `# type: ignore`, which kind of defeats the purpose

issue.title: `Self` does not work correctly with `Enum`
issue.body:
This code produces an error:

```python
from enum import Enum
from typing import Self

class MyEnum(Enum):
    A = 'a'

    @classmethod
    def a(cls) -> Self:
        return cls.A
```

Output:

```
ex.py:9: error: Incompatible return value type (got "MyEnum", expected "Self")  [return-value]
```

But, I don't think that this is correct. Because enums with members are implicitly final:

```python
>>> from enum import Enum
>>> class MyEnum(Enum):
...     A = 'a'
... 
>>> class B(MyEnum): ...
... 
Traceback (most recent call last):
    ...
TypeError: <enum 'B'> cannot extend <enum 'MyEnum'>
```

Work-around:

```python
from enum import Enum
from typing import Self, final

@final
class MyEnum(Enum):
    A = 'a'

    @classmethod
    def a(cls) -> Self:
        return cls.A
```

This happens because `@final` triggers special handling of this case here: https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/b82697b3f50056c2697ef6e884e1d6dd87881f8d/mypy/typeanal.py#L804-L806

I guess we can add a special case for that?

body:
Thanks @sobolevn for that solution.

It doesn't change that mypy appears to be falling short here. `Enum` subclasses _with members_ are required to be non-subclassable; I shouldn't have to explicitly mark them as `@final`.

From spec:

> An Enum class with one or more defined members cannot be subclassed. They are implicitly “final”. Type checkers should enforce this:

Since `mypy` considers current class assignable to `Self` when current class is final, enum treatment should be consistent with that. Typing spec does not mention relationship between `@final` and `Self` at all, and this behavior does not contradict any part of the spec language (`Foo.A` is assignable to any subtype of `Foo` because no `Foo` subtype other than `Foo` may ever exist, runtime prohibits inheriting from enum with at least one member defined).

issue.title: Consider non-empty enums assignable to Self
issue.body:
Fixes #18345.
Fixes #16558.

See the linked ticket for reasoning - enums with members are implicitly final and should be treated exactly as if they were decorated with `@final`.
